Topic.Title: YHOO TECHNICALS

Message.Msg: I'll continue to make updates as interesting things come available. Today was sort of a non-event type of day. The consolidation pattern just continues to form....nothing unusual. In fact, the market as a whole hasn't done anything too interesting. If you look at the last week or so, yes, it's going up, but in a very narrow range between a level of support and resistance. I'm really waiting to see a break in either line to make a next move. I saw a little inverse head and shoulders pattern in the SPY that predicts a move to 1560, or an equivalent percentage rise of 14,500 in the Dow. We'll see...we are very close.

Message.Title: Attacks on Mayer, Sandberg make Diversity a Joke
Message.Msg: Ask 100 men, CEOs or middle managers, about innovation effectivnes via remote workplaces and you'll get 10 different opinions. Ask them about how to get to the corporate boardroom, again you'll get many opinions.. Also, there will not be endless CNN or CNBC articles about their opinions nor blogs with a thousand comments. . However, let women like Sheryl Sandberg or Marissa Mayer express opinions that are different than the "group think" in their gender constituency and its constant articles and endless blogs (check them out for yourself) filled with vitrolic hatefulness about their "priviliged backgrounds", non-support for the average woman, etc, Regarding Yahoo this morning, now Ms. Mayer's opinions on recruiting are being challenged by some "deep throat" in the boardroom. if they can't get her on the remote workplace decision, let's attack her opinion on recruiting. All of a sudden she's gone from ex-Google wonderwinab to absolutely inept!! Lesson, don't take on the work at home crowd or the feministas. Men make these decisions everyday in corporations......no hype, no articles, nada. It mocks the true meaning of diversity in the workplace which was intended to bring divergent viewpoints in to play, looking at the other side of the coin, etc. Yet, when those opinions do not agree with "group think" in minority constitunencies.....watch out, and head for the bomb shelters. I guess diversity is just about getting more color and gender in the workplace, not divergent opinions and decisions.

Message.Msg: Alibaba Group has chosen Jonathan Lu, its Chief Data Officer who has more than a decade of experience in executive roles, to lead China's largest e-commerce company as it prepares to launch an initial public offering. Message.Title: Confession: Why I bought Yahoo at $14. Why Coldone is a bright bulb.
Message.Msg: Last year when I saw Daniel Loeb shaking things up at Yahoo, it really got my attention. I like Daniel Loeb. Very smart guy. So, when he pushed Scott Thomspon out (correctly so), then I knew this was an INVESTOR out to make money. And I let my own money follow him. Plus all the fundamentals were sooo there. I've pointed out here at the Message Board that while FaceBook boasts and boasts it's ONLY attribute of 1 Billion Unique Visitors, that Yahoo also has 700,000,000 Unique Visitors..not that many less. BUT unlike FaceBook, whose UV's are mostly in impoverished countries where a smart phone is all they own, Yahoo's UV's come to Yahoo to CHECK ON THEIR STOCK, to watch sports...In other words, Yahoo's UV's have MONEY and guess what? ADVERTISERS love that demographic. Yahoo has a bigger sports audience than ESPN! More stock watchers than Bloomberg, CNBC and the Wall Street Journal! 700,000,000. So, yes, I bought at $14 and I bought a hell of a lot. AND THEN OMG! HERE CAME MARISSA MAYER! And now Yahoo's are busy mobilizing. They are monetizing. They are advertising to that 700,000,000 audience. And that spells M-O-N-E-Y! Finally, Coldone took a lot of #$%$ here during all of that time and I lurked, not posting much, but I can tell everyone with clarity: Coldone was right and the shorters who bashed him lost their shirts and their credibility. So here's to Yahoo! Here's to Daniel Loeb and Marissa! And here's to Coldone! I am a Yahoo!

Message.Title: 2 Yahoo Takeover Targets
Message.Msg: How much money does Yahoo have to spend? Before talking about what companies Yahoo could buy, it's worth asking the question: What can it afford? On its balance sheet, Yahoo currently has just over $4 billion worth of cash, but this number is deceiving. Some of this is still pledged to repurchasing shares -- last year, Yahoo made a $3 billion commitment to buyback much of its own stock. But Yahoo could raise much, much more. A number of sell-side analysts have, in recent weeks, upgraded the stock on the possibility that it could sell off its Asian assets: its remaining stake in Alibaba, and Yahoo Japan. Combined, these could net the company over $20 billion, according to Cantor Fitzgerald. With that sort of war chest, Yahoo could go after all but the largest tech companies.
